1447.name: Gini coefficient (income after taxes and transfers) (OECD Income Distribution Database (2016))
1447.description: Gini coefficient after taxes and transfers have been made. The higher the gini, the more inequality; 1 corresponding to perfect inequality and 0 with perfect equality.

source.name: OECD Income Distribution Database (2016)
source.dataPublisherSource: OECD, Social Protection & Well-Being, Income Distribution Database
source.additionalInfo: All estimates use the new OECD methodology for calculating incomes, introduced in 2012. The source notes: "Data calculated according to the new OECD Terms of reference. Compared to previous terms of reference, these include a more detail breakdown of current transfers received and paid by households as well as a revised definition of household income, including the value of goods produced for own consumption as an element of self-employed income."

1448.name: Gini  coefficient (before taxes and transfers) (OECD Income Distribution Database (2016))
1448.description: Gini coefficient before any taxes and transfers have been made. The higher the gini, the more inequality; 1 corresponding to perfect inequality and 0 with perfect equality.

source.name: OECD Income Distribution Database (2016)
source.dataPublisherSource: OECD, Social Protection & Well-Being, Income Distribution Database
source.additionalInfo: All estimates use the new OECD methodology for calculating incomes, introduced in 2012. The source notes: "Data calculated according to the new OECD Terms of reference. Compared to previous terms of reference, these include a more detail breakdown of current transfers received and paid by households as well as a revised definition of household income, including the value of goods produced for own consumption as an element of self-employed income."
